text: For what it's worth, this will sound like bragging, but I say this to address one obvious question: two of these outlets fairly recently asked me about working on their political staffs. I suppose they recognized that I am qualified, but lots of other people are too (12.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: It is simply hard for me to believe that a fair and equitable process for hiring political reporters results in 0 non-whites being qualified for those positions and therefore being hired at some of these outlets (11.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: I'm less concerned about diversity purely for the sake of coverage. White reporters should (and I think are to some extent) covering racial issues in America and Trump. My concern is more about equity and opportunity (10.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: But my guess is that group would do more on how Trump's immigration policy affects people and less on whether Jared and Ivanka are gaining or losing power in the White House. And that is a choice (9.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: I could cover hire a team of say, Yamiche Alcindor, Astead Herndon, Laura Jarrett, Sarah Kliff, Seung Min Kim, Dara Lind, and Jack Jenkins (that was basically off the top of my head) to cover the White House and I bet that group would break news and do great features (8.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: There are plenty of qualified, talented minority reporters who are interested in politics. Ultimately, editors have to decide if they want to hire these people--even if those hires might require slightly changing how those outlets approach White House coverage (7.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: Another issue: many outlets are desperate to avoid being cast as biased against GOP. A White House team that had 3 black/Latino reporters out of 7 would more accurately reflect America than 0/7, but might not be ideal if the aim is to get palace gossip from this White House (6.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: Second issue is that many editors in DC view the WH reporter role as more about describing internal tensions (so Jared v. Bannon) than say, how Trump affects America's racial dynamics. Reporters (like myself) not particularly interested in "palace intrigue" are disadvantaged (5.)
author: perrybaconjr

text: The reporters in DC who are most followed on Twitter by other reporters in DC is a heavily-male, heavily-white group. Of the top 25, three non-white reporters. Only four are women. https://www.vox.com/2018/6/22/17489516/male-politics-reporters-only-tweet-other-men-nikki-usher … (4)
author: perrybaconjr

text: The first issue is journalism hiring, like hiring in other industries, is often about who we know, who is in our personal circle, who our circle thinks is good. And look at this analysis by Vox. (3.) http://www.vox.com/2018/6/22/17489516/male-politics-reporters-only-tweet-other- …
author: perrybaconjr

text: It is not that these outlets completely disregard racial diversity or are unaware of their shortcomings on these issues. They all have recruiting directors/editors in charge of staffing/diversity committees, etc. (2.)

text: Not a perfect tweet.Maggie is a fantastic reporter. Did not mean this as a dig at her. So is Josh Dawsey. So is Jonathan Swan. I just think on a story like a huge figure like Rosenstein resigning, we as journalists need less of an urge to be first and more of an urge to be right.

text: Many news outlets have the view that anyone can write a story, but not everyone can "break" a story. Breaking news has value, and outlets should hire IN PART for that. But the significant number of people trying to be the next Maggie Haberman is often not helpful to readers.
author: perrybaconjr

text: The "fake news" crowd is often attacking deeply-reported, accurate accountability journalism. But the endless reporting trying to be first to say Kelly or Priebus would be fired serves outlets and journalists ("we were first") but only confuses readers. They tell me this.
author: perrybaconjr

text: There has been some great access-based journalism the last two years. But there has also been way, way too much, overhyped, thinly-sourced stuff that confuses readers and over time erodes trust in the media overall.
author: perrybaconjr

text: I stopped reading Axios early last year for exactly this reason: thinly-sourced, overhyped stories that often didn't pan out. Every outlet makes mistakes. But what happened today did not match what their initial story implied.

text: This question is hard. I'm sure Clinton or Cruz would bail out banks if it would save the economy. But they can't say that.

text: Carson just really needs to bone up on the issues a bit more. He was asked about bailing out banks and he just couldn't give any details.

text: Some really strong questions from Gerard Baker tonight.

text: I would love, love for Carson and Trump to name these generals they are talking to, so I could call them.

text: This has been a good debate. Candidates came ready to disagree. Fewer people on stage gives them more time to talk.

text: I really wish the moderators would let the CANDIDATES criticize one another. They are over-learning from the CNBC debate.

text: Cruz actually forget one of his agencies. He got IRS, Commerce, Energy, HUD. His press release notes Department of Education too.

text: Cruz gave a very strong argument for opposing amnesty. Same ideas as Trump, but much more articulate in making the case.
author: perrybaconjr

text: I really wish the moderators would let the candidates debate one another. This Kasich-Trump exchange is interesting.
